lines.text: Enter POMPEY, MENECRATES, and MENAS, in warlike manner

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: If the great gods be just, they shall assist The deeds of justest men.

lines.speaker: menecrates
lines.text: Know, worthy Pompey, That what they do delay, they not deny.

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays The thing we sue for.

lines.speaker: menecrates
lines.text: We, ignorant of ourselves, Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers Deny us for our good; so find we profit By losing of our prayers.

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: I shall do well: The people love me, and the sea is mine; My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to the full. Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors: Caesar gets money where He loses hearts: Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flatter'd; but he neither loves, Nor either cares for him.

lines.speaker: menas
lines.text: Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field: a mighty strength they carry.

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: He dreams: I know they are in Rome together, Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy waned lip! Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both! Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts, Keep his brain fuming; Epicurean cooks Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite; That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honour Even till a Lethe'd dulness! How now, Varrius!

lines.speaker: varrius
lines.text: This is most certain that I shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected: since he went from Egypt 'tis A space for further travel.

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: I could have given less matter A better ear. Menas, I did not think This amorous surfeiter would have donn'd his helm For such a petty war: his soldiership Is twice the other twain: but let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck The ne'er-lust-wearied Antony.

lines.speaker: menas
lines.text: I cannot hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together: His wife that's dead did trespasses to Caesar; His brother warr'd upon him; although, I think, Not moved by Antony.

lines.speaker: pompey
lines.text: I know not, Menas, How lesser enmities may give way to greater. Were't not that we stand up against them all, 'Twere pregnant they should square between themselves; For they have entertained cause enough To draw their swords: but how the fear of us May cement their divisions and bind up The petty difference, we yet not know. Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands. Come, Menas.
